Knowing the truth of peace and war, knowing the division of inference,

translated: Delighted to see the Pāṇḍavas seated in the assembly, swift as thought,

analyzed: arcayām āsa ratnaiḥ ca sarva kāmaiḥ ca dharma vid

translated: Nārada said:

analyzed: kaccit arthāḥ ca kalpante dharme ca ramate manaḥ
translated: Do your goals prosper, and does your mind delight in dharma?

original: sukhāni cānubhūyante manaś ca na vihanyate
analyzed: sukhāni ca anubhūyante manaḥ ca na vihanyate
translated: Are you experiencing happiness, and is your mind not obstructed?

analyzed: kaccit ācaritām pūrvaiḥ naradeva pitāmahaiḥ

analyzed: vartase vṛttim akṣīṇām dharma artha sahitām nṛṣu
translated: Do you follow the inexhaustible conduct among men, which is endowed with dharma and artha?

analyzed: kaccit arthena vā dharmam dharmeṇa artham atha api vā  ubhau vā prīti sāreṇa na kāmena prabādhase  kaccit artham ca dharmam ca kāmam ca jayatām vara
translated: Do you ever obstruct dharma with artha, artha with dharma, or both with pleasure?🔽O best of victorious ones, do you always serve dharma, artha and kāma,

original: vibhajya kāle kālajña sadā varada sevase
analyzed: vibhajya kāle kāla jña sadā vara da sevase
translated: dividing them properly, O knower of time, O bestower of boons?

analyzed: kaccit rāja guṇaiḥ ṣaḍbhiḥ sapta upāyān tathā anagha
translated: O sinless one, do you examine the six royal qualities, the seven means,

analyzed: bala abalam tathā samyak caturdaśa parīkṣase
translated: and the fourteen in the proper way, regarding their strength and weakness?

original: kaccid ātmānam anvīkṣya parāṃś ca jayatāṃ vara
analyzed: kaccit ātmānam anvīkṣya parān ca jayatām vara
translated: O best of victorious ones, having examined yourself and others,

analyzed: tathā saṃdhāya karmāṇi aṣṭau bhārata sevase
translated: do you then undertake actions in the eight ways, O Bhārata?

original: kaccit prakṛtayaḥ ṣaṭ te na luptā bharatarṣabha
analyzed: kaccit prakṛtayaḥ ṣaḍ te na luptāḥ bharata ṛṣabha
translated: O bull among the Bharata people, are your six constituents not lost?

translated: Are they wealthy, free from vices, and devoted to you in every way?🔽Are your counsels ever divulged by spies or messengers, or by those who are unsuspected,

original: tvatto vā tava vāmātyair bhidyate jātu mantritam
analyzed: tvattaḥ vā tava vā amātyaiḥ bhidyate jātu mantritam

analyzed: mitra udāsīna śatrūṇām kaccit vetsi cikīrṣitam  kaccit saṃdhim yathākālam vigraham ca upasevase
translated: Do you know the intentions of your friends, neutrals, and enemies?🔽Do you make peace and war at the proper time?

original: kaccid vṛttim udāsīne madhyame cānuvartase🔽kaccid ātmasamā buddhyā śucayo jīvitakṣamāḥ
analyzed: kaccit vṛttim udāsīne madhyame ca anuvartase  kaccit ātma samāḥ buddhyā śucayaḥ jīvita kṣamāḥ
translated: Do you follow the conduct of neutrals and those in the middle?🔽O hero, have you appointed as your ministers those who are equal to yourself in intelligence, who are pure, capable of sustaining life,

original: kulīnāś cānuraktāś ca kṛtās te vīra mantriṇaḥ
analyzed: kulīnāḥ ca anuraktāḥ ca kṛtāḥ te vīra mantriṇaḥ
translated: born in noble families, and devoted to you?

analyzed: vijayaḥ mantra mūlaḥ hi rājñām bhavati bhārata
translated: For victory, O Bharata, is based on counsel for kings.

analyzed: su saṃvṛtaḥ mantra dhanaiḥ amātyaiḥ śāstra kovidaiḥ

analyzed: rāṣṭram su rakṣitam tāta śatrubhiḥ na vilupyate
translated: the kingdom is well-protected, O son, and is not plundered by enemies.

original: kaccin nidrāvaśaṃ naiṣi kaccit kāle vibudhyase
analyzed: kaccit nidrā vaśam na eṣi kaccit kāle vibudhyase
translated: Do you not fall under the sway of sleep? Do you wake up at the proper time?

analyzed: kaccit ca apararātreṣu cintayasi artham artha vid
translated: O knower of wealth, do you think about wealth during the latter part of the night?

original: kaccin mantrayase naikaḥ kaccin na bahubhiḥ saha
analyzed: kaccit mantrayase na ekaḥ kaccit na bahubhiḥ saha
translated: Do you consult alone? Do you not consult with many?

original: kaccit te mantrito mantro na rāṣṭram anudhāvati
analyzed: kaccit te mantritaḥ mantraḥ na rāṣṭram anudhāvati
translated: Has your counsel been divulged to the kingdom?

original: kaccid arthān viniścitya laghumūlān mahodayān🔽kṣipram ārabhase kartuṃ na vighnayasi tādṛśān
analyzed: kaccit arthān viniścitya laghu mūlān mahā udayān  kṣipram ārabhase kartum na vighnayasi tādṛśān
translated: Having determined the goals, which have small expenses and great results,🔽do you quickly undertake to accomplish them, without obstructing such?

original: kaccin na sarve karmāntāḥ parokṣās te viśaṅkitāḥ
analyzed: kaccit na sarve karmāntāḥ parokṣāḥ te viśaṅkitāḥ
translated: I hope all your undertakings are not done through intermediaries, nor are you suspicious of them.

original: parokṣā vā mahārāja madhyaṃ hy atra praśasyate
analyzed: parokṣā vā mahā rāja madhyam hi atra praśasyate
translated: Intermediaries are not recommended, O great king, the middle course is praised here.

original: āptair alubdhaiḥ kramikais te ca kaccid anuṣṭhitāḥ
analyzed: āptaiḥ alubdhaiḥ kramikaiḥ te ca kaccit anuṣṭhitāḥ
translated: I hope they are carried out by trustworthy, non-greedy, and regular people.

original: sarve vā punar utsṛṣṭāḥ saṃsṛṣṭaṃ hy atra kāraṇam
analyzed: sarve vā punar utsṛṣṭāḥ saṃsṛṣṭam hi atra kāraṇam
translated: All or some of them should be abandoned, for a mixture is the cause here.

original: kaccid rājan kṛtāny eva kṛtaprāyāṇi vā punaḥ
analyzed: kaccit rājan kṛtāni eva kṛta prāyāṇi vā punar
translated: O king, I hope all the tasks are either completed or almost completed,

original: vidus te vīra karmāṇi nānavāptāni kāni cit
analyzed: viduḥ te vīra karmāṇi na anavāptāni kāni cit
translated: and you know of them, O hero, and not of any that are incomplete.

analyzed: kaccit kāraṇikāḥ sarve sarva śāstreṣu kovidāḥ
translated: I hope all the accountants are well-versed in all the scriptures,

original: kārayanti kumārāṃś ca yodhamukhyāṃś ca sarvaśaḥ
analyzed: kārayanti kumārān ca yodha mukhyān ca sarvaśas
translated: and they make the princes and all the chief warriors do their duties.

original: kaccit sahasrair mūrkhāṇām ekaṃ krīṇāsi paṇḍitam
analyzed: kaccit sahasraiḥ mūrkhāṇām ekam krīṇāsi paṇḍitam
translated: I hope you exchange a thousand fools for a single wise man,

original: paṇḍito hy arthakṛcchreṣu kuryān niḥśreyasaṃ param🔽kaccid durgāṇi sarvāṇi dhanadhānyāyudhodakaiḥ
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ hi artha kṛcchreṣu kuryāt niḥśreyasam param  kaccit durgāṇi sarvāṇi dhana dhānya āyudha udakaiḥ
translated: for a wise man can bring about the highest good in times of difficulty.🔽I hope all the forts are filled with wealth, grain, weapons, water,

analyzed: yantraiḥ ca paripūrṇāni tathā śilpi dhanurdharaiḥ
translated: machines, craftsmen, and archers,

original: eko 'py amātyo medhāvī śūro dānto vicakṣaṇaḥ
analyzed: ekaḥ pi amātyaḥ medhāvī śūraḥ dāntaḥ vicakṣaṇaḥ
translated: Even a single minister who is wise, brave, self-controlled, and skilled

original: rājānaṃ rājaputraṃ vā prāpayen mahatīṃ śriyam
analyzed: rājānam rāja putram vā prāpayet mahatīm śriyam
translated: can bring great prosperity to a king or prince.

original: kaccid aṣṭādaśānyeṣu svapakṣe daśa pañca ca
analyzed: kaccit aṣṭādaśa anyeṣu sva pakṣe daśa pañca ca
translated: Do you know the eighteen other tirthas, the fifteen on your own side,

original: tribhis tribhir avijñātair vetsi tīrthāni cārakaiḥ🔽kaccid dviṣām aviditaḥ pratiyattaś ca sarvadā
analyzed: tribhiḥ tribhiḥ avijñātaiḥ vetsi tīrthāni cārakaiḥ  kaccit dviṣām a viditaḥ pratiyattaḥ ca sarvadā
translated: and the three on each side, through three unknown spies?🔽Are you always vigilant and ready, unknown to your enemies,

original: nityayukto ripūn sarvān vīkṣase ripusūdana🔽kaccid vinayasaṃpannaḥ kulaputro bahuśrutaḥ
analyzed: nitya yuktaḥ ripūn sarvān vīkṣase ripu sūdana  kaccit vinaya saṃpannaḥ kula putraḥ bahu śrutaḥ
translated: looking at all your enemies, O destroyer of enemies?🔽Is your priest honored by you, endowed with humility, born in a noble family, learned,

original: anasūyur anupraṣṭā satkṛtas te purohitaḥ🔽kaccid agniṣu te yukto vidhijño matimān ṛjuḥ
analyzed: anasūyuḥ anupraṣṭā satkṛtaḥ te purohitaḥ  kaccit agniṣu te yuktaḥ vidhi jñaḥ matimān ṛjuḥ
translated: not envious, and one who asks questions?🔽Is he always informed at the right time about what has been offered and what is to be offered in the fires,

original: hutaṃ ca hoṣyamāṇaṃ ca kāle vedayate sadā🔽kaccid aṅgeṣu niṣṇāto jyotiṣāṃ pratipādakaḥ
analyzed: hutam ca hoṣyamāṇam ca kāle vedayate sadā  kaccit aṅgeṣu niṣṇātaḥ jyotiṣām pratipādakaḥ
translated: engaged in the rituals, wise, and honest?

original: utpāteṣu ca sarveṣu daivajñaḥ kuśalas tava🔽kaccin mukhyā mahatsv eva madhyameṣu ca madhyamāḥ
analyzed: utpāteṣu ca sarveṣu daiva jñaḥ kuśalaḥ tava  kaccit mukhyāḥ mahatsu eva madhyameṣu ca madhyamāḥ
translated: Is your astrologer skilled in all the limbs of astrology,🔽and in all the portents?🔽Are the chief servants employed in the great tasks, the middling in the middling,

original: jaghanyāś ca jaghanyeṣu bhṛtyāḥ karmasu yojitāḥ
analyzed: jaghanyāḥ ca jaghanyeṣu bhṛtyāḥ karmasu yojitāḥ
translated: and the lowest in the lowest tasks?🔽Do you employ as ministers those who are beyond suspicion, pure,

analyzed: amātyān upadhā atītān pitṛpaitāmahām śucīn
translated: and descended from your father and grandfather?

original: śreṣṭhāñ śreṣṭheṣu kaccit tvaṃ niyojayasi karmasu🔽kaccin nogreṇa daṇḍena bhṛśam udvejitaprajāḥ
analyzed: śreṣṭhām śreṣṭheṣu kaccit tvam niyojayasi karmasu  kaccit nā ugreṇa daṇḍena bhṛśam udvejita prajāḥ
translated: Do you employ the best people for the best jobs?

analyzed: rāṣṭram tava anuśāsanti mantriṇaḥ bharata ṛṣabha
translated: Do your ministers rule the kingdom without greatly agitating the people with harsh punishments, O best of the Bharata race?

original: kaccit tvāṃ nāvajānanti yājakāḥ patitaṃ yathā
analyzed: kaccit tvām na avajānanti yājakāḥ patitam yathā
translated: Do the priests not despise you as if you were fallen,

analyzed: ugra pratigrahītāram kāmayānam iva striyaḥ
translated: or those who receive harsh gifts, like women who desire?

original: kaccin na vidyate rāṣṭre tava kīrtivināśakāḥ🔽kaccid dhṛṣṭaś ca śūraś ca matimān dhṛtimāñ śuciḥ
analyzed: kaccit na vidyate rāṣṭre tava kīrti vināśakāḥ  kaccit dhṛṣṭaḥ ca śūraḥ ca matimān dhṛtimān śuciḥ
translated: Are there none in your kingdom who destroy your fame?🔽Is your general cheerful, brave, intelligent, steadfast, pure,

original: kulīnaś cānuraktaś ca dakṣaḥ senāpatis tava
analyzed: kulīnaḥ ca anuraktaḥ ca dakṣaḥ senāpatiḥ tava
translated: of noble birth, devoted, and skilled?

original: kaccid balasya te mukhyāḥ sarve yuddhaviśāradāḥ
analyzed: kaccit balasya te mukhyāḥ sarve yuddha viśāradāḥ
translated: Are all the chieftains of your army skilled in battle,

original: dṛṣṭāpadānā vikrāntās tvayā satkṛtya mānitāḥ🔽kaccid balasya bhaktaṃ ca vetanaṃ ca yathocitam
analyzed: dṛṣṭa apadānāḥ vikrāntāḥ tvayā satkṛtya mānitāḥ  kaccit balasya bhaktam ca vetanam ca yathocitam
translated: their exploits seen, and are they honored and respected by you?🔽Do you give the army its food and wages as is proper,

analyzed: saṃprāpta kālam dātavyam dadāsi na vikarṣasi
translated: at the right time, and do you not delay?

analyzed: kāla atikramaṇāt hi ete bhakta vetanayoḥ bhṛtāḥ
translated: For when the army is paid its food and wages after the proper time has passed,

original: bhartuḥ kupyanti daurgatyāt so 'narthaḥ sumahān smṛtaḥ
analyzed: bhartuḥ kupyanti daurgatyāt saḥ narthaḥ su mahān smṛtaḥ
translated: it becomes angry with the master due to the difficulty, and that is remembered as a great misfortune.

original: kaccit sarve mahīpālās tvadājñā mūrdhni dhāritāḥ
analyzed: kaccit sarve mahīpālāḥ tvad ājñāḥ mūrdhni dhāritāḥ
translated: Are all the kings bearing your command on their heads?

original: kaccit suhṛhayāḥ sarve hy arcayanti bhavatkṛte
analyzed: kaccit suhṛhayāḥ sarve hi arcayanti bhavat kṛte
translated: Are all your friends and allies worshipping you for your sake?

original: kaccid antapurā devā kāle saṃsevitās tvayā🔽kaccid rājapurandhrībhiḥ prasūyante kulocitāḥ
analyzed: kaccit kāle saṃsevitāḥ tvayā  kaccit rāja purandhrībhiḥ prasūyante kula ucitāḥ
translated: O God, are the women of the inner apartments attended to by you at the proper time?🔽Are the daughters-in-law of the king giving birth to children befitting the family?

analyzed: kumārāḥ dhārmikāḥ śūrāḥ rāja dharma viśāradāḥ
translated: Are the princes virtuous, heroic and well-versed in the duties of kings?

original: kaccit teṣāṃ ca putrāṇāṃ vivāhaḥ kriyate tvayā
analyzed: kaccit teṣām ca putrāṇām vivāhaḥ kriyate tvayā
translated: Are their marriages being celebrated by you?

original: saṃtānārthaṃ tu vaṃśasya doṣaṃ tasya mahīyasaḥ🔽kaccid āśvāsirājaṃs tvayā śaraṇam āgatān
analyzed: saṃtāna artham tu vaṃśasya doṣam tasya mahīyasaḥ  kaccit āśvāsi rājan tvayā śaraṇam āgatān
translated: For the sake of perpetuating the line, the fault of that great one?🔽O king, are you greatly comforting the gods and others who have come to you for refuge,

analyzed: deva ādīn bhaya saṃtrastān akārpaṇya dhiyā bhṛśam
translated: who are terrified with fear, with a mind free from miserliness?

analyzed: kaccit sarve nuraktāḥ tvām kula putrāḥ pradhānataḥ
translated: Are all the noble and foremost men devoted to you?

original: kaccit prāṇāṃs tavārtheṣu saṃtyajanti sadā yudhi🔽kaccin naiko bahūn arthān sarvaśaḥ sāṃparāyikān
analyzed: kaccit prāṇān tava artheṣu saṃtyajanti sadā yudhi  kaccit na ekaḥ bahūn arthān sarvaśas sāṃparāyikān
translated: Are they always ready to lay down their lives for your sake in battle?🔽Do you, being self-willed and disobedient to commands,

original: anuśāssi yathākāmaṃ kāmātmā śāsanātigaḥ🔽kaccit puruṣakāreṇa puruṣaḥ karma śobhayan
analyzed: anuśāssi yathākāmam kāma ātmā śāsana atigaḥ  kaccit puruṣakāreṇa puruṣaḥ karma śobhayan
translated: rule over many men and all the worldly and other-worldly affairs as you desire,🔽and obtain greater honor and more wages?

original: labhate mānam adhikaṃ bhūyo vā bhaktavetanam
analyzed: labhate mānam adhikam bhūyas vā bhakta vetanam
translated: Is a man, beautifying his work by manly effort,

analyzed: kaccit vidyā vinītān ca narām jñāna viśāradān
translated: Do you honour with gifts those men who are humble and learned, and who are skilled in knowledge,

analyzed: yathārham guṇataḥ ca eva dānena abhyavapadyase
translated: according to their worth and their virtues?

original: kaccid dārān manuṣyāṇāṃ tavārthe mṛtyum eyuṣām
analyzed: kaccit dārān manuṣyāṇām tava arthe mṛtyum eyuṣām
translated: Do you support the wives of men who have died for your sake,

original: vyasanaṃ cābhyupetānāṃ bibharṣi bharatarṣabha🔽kaccid bhayād upanataṃ klībaṃ vā ripum āgatam
analyzed: vyasanam ca abhyupetānām bibharṣi bharata ṛṣabha  kaccit bhayāt upanatam klībam vā ripum āgatam
translated: and those who have fallen into misfortune, O best of the Bharata lineage?🔽Do you protect, O Partha, those who have come to you out of fear, or those who are impotent or have come as enemies,

original: yuddhe vā vijitaṃ pārtha putravat parirakṣasi
analyzed: yuddhe vā vijitam pārtha putra vat parirakṣasi
translated: or those who have been defeated in battle, as if they were your own sons?

original: kaccit tvam eva sarvasyāḥ pṛthivyāḥ pṛthivīpate
analyzed: kaccit tvam eva sarvasyāḥ pṛthivyāḥ pṛthivīpate
translated: Do you, O lord of the earth, treat all the people of the entire earth

original: samaś ca nābhiśaṅkyaś ca yathā mātā yathā pitā
analyzed: samaḥ ca na abhiśaṅkyaḥ ca yathā mātā yathā pitā
translated: equally and without suspicion, as if they were your mother or father?

original: kaccid vyasaninaṃ śatruṃ niśamya bharatarṣabha🔽abhiyāsi javenaiva samīkṣya trividhaṃ balam
analyzed: kaccit vyasaninam śatrum niśamya bharata ṛṣabha  abhiyāsi javena eva samīkṣya trividham balam
translated: Having heard that an enemy is in distress, O best of the Bharata lineage,🔽do you quickly march out, having considered the three kinds of strength?

analyzed: yātrām ārabhase diṣṭyā prāpta kālam ariṃdama
translated: Fortunate it is that you undertake an expedition at the right time, O destroyer of enemies.

original: pārṣṇimūlaṃ ca vijñāya vyavasāyaṃ parājayam🔽balasya ca mahārāja dattvā vetanam agrataḥ🔽kaccic ca balamukhyebhyaḥ pararāṣṭre paraṃtapa
analyzed: pārṣṇi mūlam ca vijñāya vyavasāyam parājayam  balasya ca mahā rāja dattvā vetanam agratas  kaccit ca bala mukhyebhyaḥ para rāṣṭre paraṃtapa
translated: Having understood the root of the heel, the resolve, and the defeat,🔽and having given the army its wages in advance,🔽do you, O scorcher of enemies, give to the chieftains of the army in the enemy's kingdom,

analyzed: upacchannāni ratnāni prayacchasi yathārhataḥ
translated: hidden treasures as they deserve?

original: kaccid ātmānam evāgre vijitya vijitendriyaḥ🔽parāñ jigīṣase pārtha pramattān ajitendriyān
analyzed: kaccit ātmānam eva agre vijitya vijita indriyaḥ  parām jigīṣase pārtha pramattān ajita indriyān
translated: Have you first conquered yourself and controlled your senses,

original: kaccit te yāsyataḥ śatrūn pūrvaṃ yānti svanuṣṭhitāḥ
analyzed: kaccit te yāsyataḥ śatrūn pūrvam yānti su anuṣṭhitāḥ
translated: and do you wish to conquer others, O Partha, who are heedless and have uncontrolled senses?

original: sāma dānaṃ ca bhedaś ca daṇḍaś ca vidhivad guṇāḥ
analyzed: sāma dānam ca bhedaḥ ca daṇḍaḥ ca vidhivat guṇāḥ
translated: Do your well-established means of conciliation, gifts, dissension and punishment,🔽proceed against your enemies before you go against them?

original: kaccin mūlaṃ dṛḍhaṃ kṛtvā yātrāṃ yāsi viśāṃ pate
analyzed: kaccit mūlam dṛḍham kṛtvā yātrām yāsi viśām pate
translated: Do you undertake your expeditions after having laid a firm foundation,

original: tāṃś ca vikramase jetuṃ jitvā ca parirakṣasi
analyzed: tān ca vikramase jetum jitvā ca parirakṣasi
translated: and do you strive to conquer them and protect them after having conquered them?

analyzed: kaccit aṣṭa aṅga saṃyuktā caturvidha balā camūḥ
translated: Do your army consisting of four kinds of forces and endowed with eight constituents,

original: balamukhyaiḥ sunītā te dviṣatāṃ pratibādhanī🔽kaccil lavaṃ ca muṣṭiṃ ca pararāṣṭre paraṃtapa
analyzed: bala mukhyaiḥ su nītā te dviṣatām pratibādhanī  kaccit lavam ca muṣṭim ca para rāṣṭre paraṃtapa
translated: well-governed by your chieftains, obstruct your enemies?

analyzed: a vihāya mahā rāja vihaṃsi samare ripūn
translated: Do you, O scorcher of enemies, fight with your enemies in battle, O great king, without abandoning your sword and shield in the enemy's kingdom?

analyzed: kaccit sva para rāṣṭreṣu bahavaḥ dhi kṛtāḥ tava
translated: Do you have many officers in your own and enemy kingdoms

original: arthān samanutiṣṭhanti rakṣanti ca parasparam🔽kaccid abhyavahāryāṇi gātrasaṃsparśakāni ca
analyzed: arthān samanutiṣṭhanti rakṣanti ca parasparam  kaccit abhyavahāryāṇi gātra saṃsparśakāni ca
translated: who carry out their duties and protect each other?

original: ghreyāṇi ca mahārāja rakṣanty anumatās tava
analyzed: ghreyāṇi ca mahā rāja rakṣanti anumatāḥ tava
translated: Do you, O great king, have those who are approved by you to protect your food,🔽those that come in contact with your body, and those that are to be smelt?

original: kaccit kośaṃ ca koṣṭhaṃ ca vāhanaṃ dvāram āyudham
analyzed: kaccit kośam ca koṣṭham ca vāhanam dvāram āyudham
translated: Do you have your treasury, granary, transport, gates and weapons

original: āyaś ca kṛtakalyāṇais tava bhaktair anuṣṭhitaḥ🔽kaccid ābhyantarebhyaś ca bāhyebhyaś ca viśāṃ pate
analyzed: āyaḥ ca kṛta kalyāṇaiḥ tava bhaktaiḥ anuṣṭhitaḥ  kaccit ābhyantarebhyaḥ ca bāhyebhyaḥ ca viśām pate
translated: And is the income being properly collected by your well-wishers and devotees?🔽O lord of the people, do you first protect yourself from your own people and from outsiders,

original: rakṣasy ātmānam evāgre tāṃś ca svebhyo mithaś ca tān🔽kaccin na pāne dyūte vā krīḍāsu pramadāsu ca
analyzed: rakṣasi ātmānam eva agre tān ca svebhyaḥ mithas ca tān  kaccit na pāne dyūte vā krīḍāsu pramadāsu ca
translated: and then them from each other?

original: pratijānanti pūrvāhṇe vyayaṃ vyasanajaṃ tava🔽kaccid āyasya cārdhena caturbhāgena vā punaḥ
analyzed: pratijānanti pūrvāhṇe vyayam vyasana jam tava  kaccit āyasya ca ardhena catur bhāgena vā punar
translated: Do they inform you in the morning about the expenses incurred due to drinking, gambling, sports, and women?🔽Is your expenditure being met by half, a quarter,

original: pādabhāgais tribhir vāpi vyayaḥ saṃśodhyate tava🔽kaccij jñātīn gurūn vṛddhān vaṇijaḥ śilpinaḥ śritān
analyzed: pāda bhāgaiḥ tribhiḥ vā api vyayaḥ saṃśodhyate tava  kaccit jñātīn gurūn vṛddhān vaṇijaḥ śilpinaḥ śritān
translated: or three-fourths of your income?

analyzed: abhīkṣṇam anugṛhṇāsi dhana dhānyena durgatān
translated: Do you frequently help your relatives, elders, the aged, traders, artisans, and the poor with wealth and grain?

analyzed: kaccit āya vyaye yuktāḥ sarve gaṇaka lekhakāḥ
translated: Are all your accountants and clerks engaged in income and expenditure,

original: anutiṣṭhanti pūrvāhṇe nityam āyavyayaṃ tava🔽kaccid artheṣu saṃprauḍhān hitakāmān anupriyān
analyzed: anutiṣṭhanti pūrvāhṇe nityam āya vyayam tava  kaccit artheṣu saṃprauḍhān hita kāmān anupriyān
translated: and do they always present your daily income and expenditure to you in the morning?🔽Do you not remove from their duties those who are mature in affairs, well-wishers, and agreeable,

analyzed: na apakarṣasi karmabhyaḥ pūrvam a prāpya kilbiṣam
translated: without first finding fault with them?

analyzed: kaccit viditvā puruṣān uttama adhama madhyamān
translated: Having known the men to be superior, middling, and inferior,

analyzed: tvam karmasu anurūpeṣu niyojayasi bhārata
translated: do you employ them in tasks befitting them, O descendant of Bharata?

original: kaccin na lubdhāś caurā vā vairiṇo vā viśāṃ pate
analyzed: kaccit na lubdhāḥ caurāḥ vā vairiṇaḥ vā viśām pate
translated: Are the people not oppressed by greedy, thieving, or hostile officials, O lord of the people,

original: aprāptavyavahārā vā tava karmasv anuṣṭhitāḥ🔽kaccin na lubdhaiś caurair vā kumāraiḥ strībalena vā
analyzed: aprāpta vyavahārāḥ vā tava karmasu anuṣṭhitāḥ  kaccit na lubdhaiḥ cauraiḥ vā kumāraiḥ strī balena vā
translated: or by those who are not qualified to carry out their duties?

original: tvayā vā pīḍyate rāṣṭraṃ kaccit puṣṭāḥ kṛṣīvalāḥ🔽kaccid rāṣṭre taḍāgāni pūrṇāni ca mahānti ca
analyzed: tvayā vā pīḍyate rāṣṭram kaccit puṣṭāḥ kṛṣīvalāḥ  kaccit rāṣṭre taḍāgāni pūrṇāni ca mahānti ca
translated: Are the people of your kingdom oppressed by greedy, thieving, or youthful officials, or by women? Are they oppressed by you? Are the farmers prosperous?

analyzed: bhāgaśas viniviṣṭāni na kṛṣiḥ devamātṛkā
translated: Are the large and full ponds in your kingdom distributed in proper proportions? Is agriculture not dependent on the rains?

original: kaccid bījaṃ ca bhaktaṃ ca karṣakāyāvasīdate
analyzed: kaccit bījam ca bhaktam ca karṣakāya avasīdate
translated: Are seeds and food given to the farmers who are in distress?

original: pratikaṃ ca śataṃ vṛddhyā dadāsy ṛṇam anugraham
analyzed: pratikam ca śatam vṛddhyā dadāsi ṛṇam anugraham
translated: Do you give loans at a rate of interest of one hundred for one?

analyzed: kacid te dayitāḥ sarve kṛṣi gorakṣa jīvinaḥ
translated: Are all those who live by agriculture and cattle-keeping dear to you?

original: kaccit svanuṣṭhitā tāta vārttā te sādhubhir janaiḥ
analyzed: kaccit su anuṣṭhitā tāta vārttā te sādhubhiḥ janaiḥ
translated: O father, are the people who are engaged in agriculture and cattle-keeping well-treated by you?

original: vārttāyāṃ saṃśritas tāta loko 'yaṃ sukham edhate
analyzed: vārttāyām saṃśritaḥ tāta lokaḥ yam sukham edhate
translated: O father, this world depends on agriculture for its happiness.

original: kaccic chucikṛtaḥ prājñāḥ pañca pañca svanuṣṭhitāḥ
analyzed: kaccit śuci kṛtaḥ prājñāḥ pañca pañca su anuṣṭhitāḥ
translated: O king, are the five wise men, who are pure and devoted to their own duties,

original: kṣemaṃ kurvanti saṃhatya rājañ janapade tava
analyzed: kṣemam kurvanti saṃhatya rājam janapade tava
translated: working together for the welfare of your country?

analyzed: kaccit nagara gupti artham grāmāḥ nagara vat kṛtāḥ
translated: Are the villages made like cities for the protection of the cities?

original: grāmavac ca kṛtā rakṣā te ca sarve tadarpaṇāḥ
analyzed: grāma vat ca kṛtā rakṣā te ca sarve tad arpaṇāḥ
translated: And are they all devoted to him?

analyzed: kaccit balena anugatāḥ samāni viṣamāṇi ca
translated: Are they followed by the army, on even and uneven terrain?

analyzed: purāṇa caurāḥ sa adhyakṣāḥ caranti viṣaye tava
translated: Are old thieves, with their eyes on the reward, moving in your kingdom?

original: kaccit striyaḥ sāntvayasi kaccit tāś ca surakṣitāḥ
analyzed: kaccit striyaḥ sāntvayasi kaccit tāḥ ca su rakṣitāḥ
translated: Do you comfort your wives? Are they well protected?

original: kaccin na śraddadhāsy āsāṃ kaccid guhyaṃ na bhāṣase
analyzed: kaccit na śraddadhāsi āsām kaccit guhyam na bhāṣase
translated: Do you not believe them? Do you not speak secrets to them?

original: kaccic cārān niśi śrutvā tat kāryam anucintya ca
analyzed: kaccit cārān niśi śrutvā tat kāryam anucintya ca
translated: Having listened to the spies at night and having thought about their work,

analyzed: priyāṇi anubhavam śeṣe viditvā abhyantaram janam
translated: Do you go to sleep after knowing the people within?

original: kaccid dvau prathamau yāmau rātryāṃ suptvā viśāṃ pate
analyzed: kaccit dvau prathamau yāmau rātryām suptvā viśām pate
translated: Having slept during the first two watches of the night, O lord of the people,

analyzed: saṃcintayasi dharma arthau yāme utthāya paścime
translated: Do you think about dharma and artha after rising in the last watch?

analyzed: kaccit darśayase nityam manuṣyān samalaṃkṛtān
translated: Do you always show men well adorned,

original: utthāya kāle kālajñaḥ saha pāṇḍava mantribhiḥ
analyzed: utthāya kāle kāla jñaḥ saha pāṇḍava mantribhiḥ
translated: Rising at the right time, O knower of time, together with your Pandava ministers?

original: kaccid raktāmbaradharāḥ khaḍgahastāḥ svalaṃkṛtāḥ🔽abhitas tvām upāsante rakṣaṇārtham ariṃdama
analyzed: kaccit rakta ambara dharāḥ khaḍga hastāḥ su alaṃkṛtāḥ  abhitas tvām upāsante rakṣaṇa artham ariṃdama
translated: Are they dressed in red garments, with swords in their hands, well adorned,🔽Attending on you from all sides for the sake of protection, O destroyer of enemies?

original: kaccid daṇḍyeṣu yamavat pūjyeṣu ca viśāṃ pate
analyzed: kaccit daṇḍyeṣu yama vat pūjyeṣu ca viśām pate
translated: Do you punish those who deserve punishment and honour those who deserve honour, O lord of the people?

original: parīkṣya vartase samyag apriyeṣu priyeṣu ca🔽kaccic chārīram ābādham auṣadhair niyamena vā
analyzed: parīkṣya vartase samyak apriyeṣu priyeṣu ca  kaccit śārīram ābādham auṣadhaiḥ niyamena vā
translated: You act properly after examining what is agreeable and disagreeable?🔽Do you always remove physical illness with medicines or restraints,

analyzed: mānasam vṛddha sevābhiḥ sadā pārtha apakarṣasi
translated: and mental illness with the service of the aged, O son of Pritha?

original: kaccid vaidyāś cikitsāyām aṣṭāṅgāyāṃ viśāradāḥ🔽suhṛdaś cānuraktāś ca śarīre te hitāḥ sadā
analyzed: kaccit vaidyāḥ cikitsāyām aṣṭa aṅgāyām viśāradāḥ  suhṛdaḥ ca anuraktāḥ ca śarīre te hitāḥ sadā
translated: Are your physicians skilled in the eight branches of medical treatment,🔽and are your friends devoted to you, always seeking your physical well-being?

original: kaccin na mānān mohād vā kāmād vāpi viśāṃ pate🔽arthipratyarthinaḥ prāptān apāsyasi kathaṃ cana
analyzed: kiṃcid na mānāt mohāt vā kāmāt vā api viśām pate  arthi pratyarthinaḥ prāptān apāsyasi katham cana
translated: O lord of the people, do you ever ignore litigants and counter-litigants who have come to you,

original: kaccin na lobhān mohād vā viśrambhāt praṇayena vā
analyzed: kaccit na lobhāt mohāt vā viśrambhāt praṇayena vā
translated: out of pride, delusion, or desire?

original: āśritānāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ vṛttiṃ tvaṃ saṃruṇatsi ca🔽kaccid artheṣu saṃprauḍhān arthakarmavicakṣaṇān
analyzed: āśritānām manuṣyāṇām vṛttim tvam saṃruṇatsi ca  kaccit artheṣu saṃprauḍhān artha karma vicakṣaṇān
translated: Do you ever obstruct the livelihood of people who depend on you,🔽out of greed, delusion, trust, or affection?🔽Do you ever demote from their duties those who are mature in wealth and skilled in the affairs of wealth,

original: nāpakarṣasi karmabhyo hy arthayuktā itīva hi🔽kaccit paurā na sahitā ye ca te rāṣṭravāsinaḥ
analyzed: na apakarṣasi karmabhyaḥ hi artha yuktāḥ iti iva hi  kaccit paurāḥ na sahitāḥ ye ca te rāṣṭra vāsinaḥ
translated: thinking they are too preoccupied with wealth?🔽Do the citizens and the residents of your kingdom

original: tvayā saha virudhyante paraiḥ krītāḥ kathaṃ cana
analyzed: tvayā saha virudhyante paraiḥ krītāḥ katham cana
translated: ever rebel against you, bought off by your enemies in some way?

analyzed: kaccit te durbalaḥ śatruḥ balena upanipīḍitaḥ
translated: Do you ever oppress a weak enemy with your strength,

original: mantreṇa balavān kaś cid ubhābhyāṃ vā yudhiṣṭhira
analyzed: mantreṇa balavān kaḥ cit ubhābhyām vā yudhiṣṭhira
translated: or a powerful enemy with counsel, or both with both, O Yudhishthira?

analyzed: atharvavedaḥ ca tathā parvāṇi ca viśām pate

analyzed: itihāsa upavedāḥ ca vedāṅgāni ca sarvaśas

analyzed: grahāḥ yajñāḥ ca somaḥ ca daivatāni ca sarvaśas

The Savitri, the remover of misfortune, and the seven kinds of speech,

analyzed: medhā dhṛtiḥ śrutiḥ ca eva prajñā buddhiḥ yaśaḥ kṣamā

analyzed: nāṭakāḥ vividhāḥ kāvyāḥ kathā ākhyāyika kārikāḥ

analyzed: kālakā surabhiḥ devī saramā ca atha gautamī

analyzed: gārhapatyāḥ nāka carāḥ pitaraḥ loka viśrutāḥ

original: prajāvatāṃ ca pañcāśad ṛṣīṇām api pāṇḍava
analyzed: prajāvatām ca pañcāśat ṛṣīṇām api pāṇḍava

analyzed: te sma tatra yathākāmam dṛṣṭvā sarve divaukasaḥ
translated: those dwellers of heaven, having seen everything there as they wished,

original: praṇamya śirasā tasmai pratiyānti yathāgatam🔽atithīn āgatān devān daityān nāgān munīṃs tathā🔽yakṣān suparṇān kāleyān gandharvāpsarasas tathā
analyzed: praṇamya śirasā tasmai pratiyānti yathāgatam  atithīn āgatān devān daityān nāgān munīn tathā  yakṣān suparṇān kāleyān gandharva apsarasaḥ tathā
translated: bowing their heads to him, return as they came.

analyzed: mahābhāgān amita dhīḥ brahmā lokapitāmahaḥ
translated: Brahma, the grandfather of the worlds, of immeasurable intelligence,

analyzed: dayāvān sarva bhūteṣu yathārham pratipadyate
translated: compassionate towards all beings, receives as befits them,🔽the gods, demons, serpents, sages, yakshas, suparnas, kalakeyas, gandharvas and apsaras who come as guests.

analyzed: pratigṛhya ca viśvātmā svayaṃbhūḥ amita prabhaḥ
translated: Having accepted them, the self-existent one, the soul of the universe, of immeasurable splendor,

analyzed: madhureṇa sāmnā bhagavān pratigṛhṇāti nityaśas
translated: the Blessed One always receives them with sweet words.

analyzed: sāntva māna artha saṃbhogaiḥ yunakti manuja adhipa
translated: O lord of men, he unites them with conciliation, gifts, and enjoyment.

original: tathā tair upayātaiś ca pratiyātaiś ca bhārata
analyzed: tathā taiḥ upayātaiḥ ca pratiyātaiḥ ca bhārata

analyzed: ākulā sā sabhā tāta bhavati sma sukha pradā

analyzed: sarva tejaḥ mayī divyā brahmarṣi gaṇa sevitā

analyzed: brāhmyā śriyā dīpyamānā śuśubhe vigata klamā

original: sā sabhā tādṛśī dṛṣṭā sarvalokeṣu durlabhā
analyzed: sā sabhā tādṛśī dṛṣṭā sarva lokeṣu durlabhā
translated: Such an assembly was seen, difficult to find in all the worlds.

analyzed: sabhā iyam rāja śārdūla manuṣyeṣu yathā tava
translated: This assembly, O tiger among kings, is the best among men, just as yours is.

original: etā mayā dṛṣṭapūrvāḥ sabhā deveṣu pāṇḍava
analyzed: etāḥ mayā dṛṣṭa pūrvāḥ sabhāḥ deveṣu pāṇḍava
translated: O Pandava, these are the assemblies I have seen among the gods.

analyzed: tava iyam mānuṣe loke sarva śreṣṭhatamā sabhā
translated: This assembly of yours is the best of all in the human world.

analyzed: yudhiṣṭhiraḥ uvāca
translated: Yudhishthira said:

original: prāyaśo rājalokas te kathito vadatāṃ vara
analyzed: prāyaśas rāja lokaḥ te kathitaḥ vadatām vara
translated: O best of speakers, you have described mostly the assembly of kings.

original: vaivasvatasabhāyāṃ tu yathā vadasi vai prabho
analyzed: vaivasvata sabhāyām tu yathā vadasi vai prabho
translated: O lord, as you describe the assembly of Vaivasvata,

original: varuṇasya sabhāyāṃ tu nāgās te kathitā vibho
analyzed: varuṇasya sabhāyām tu nāgāḥ te kathitāḥ vibho
translated: in Varuna's assembly, O lord, the Nagas have been mentioned,

original: daityendrāś caiva bhūyiṣṭhāḥ saritaḥ sāgarās tathā
analyzed: daitya indrāḥ ca eva bhūyiṣṭhāḥ saritaḥ sāgarāḥ tathā

original: tathā dhanapater yakṣā guhyakā rākṣasās tathā
analyzed: tathā dhanapateḥ yakṣāḥ guhyakāḥ rākṣasāḥ tathā
translated: And in the assembly of the lord of wealth, the Yakshas, the Guhyakas, and the Rakshasas,

analyzed: gandharva apsarasaḥ ca eva bhagavān ca vṛṣadhvajaḥ
translated: the Gandharvas, the Apsaras, and the illustrious Shiva, the bearer of the bull.

analyzed: pitāmaha sabhāyām tu kathitāḥ te mahā ṛṣayaḥ
translated: In the assembly of the grandfather, those great sages,

analyzed: sarva deva nikāyāḥ ca sarva śāstrāṇi ca eva hi

original: snehabaddhas tu pitṛvan manasā bhaktimāṃs tvayi
analyzed: sneha baddhaḥ tu pitṛ vat manasā bhaktimān tvayi
translated: But he is bound to you by affection, like a father, and is devoted to you in mind.

original: pratīcyāṃ dakṣiṇaṃ cāntaṃ pṛthivyāḥ pāti yo nṛpaḥ
analyzed: pratīcyām dakṣiṇam ca antam pṛthivyāḥ pāti yaḥ nṛpaḥ
translated: The king who rules the southern part of the western region,

original: te cāpi praṇatās tasya mahātmāno bhayārditāḥ
analyzed: te ca api praṇatāḥ tasya mahātmānaḥ bhaya arditāḥ
translated: They too, afflicted with fear, bowed down to him, those great souls.

analyzed: mātulaḥ bhavataḥ śūraḥ purujit kunti vardhanaḥ
translated: Your maternal uncle, the brave Purujit, the enhancer of Kunti's joy,

original: sa te saṃnatimān ekaḥ snehataḥ śatrutāpanaḥ
analyzed: sa te saṃnatimān ekaḥ snehataḥ śatru tāpanaḥ
translated: He alone, out of affection, is inclined towards you, O tormentor of enemies.

original: jarāsaṃdhaṃ gatas tv evaṃ purā yo na mayā hataḥ
analyzed: jarāsaṃdham gataḥ tu evam purā yaḥ na mayā hataḥ
translated: He went to Jarasandha, whom I did not kill earlier,

analyzed: puruṣa uttama vijñātaḥ sau cediṣu durmatiḥ
translated: The evil-minded one who is known as the best of men among the Chedis,

analyzed: ātmānam pratijānāti loke smin puruṣottamam
translated: Who considers himself the best of men in this world,

original: ādatte satataṃ mohād yaḥ sa cihnaṃ ca māmakam
analyzed: ādatte satatam mohāt yaḥ sa cihnam ca māmakam
translated: Who always foolishly takes my mark,

analyzed: vaṅga puṇḍra kirāteṣu rājā bala samanvitaḥ
translated: The king endowed with strength among the Vangas, Pundras and Kiratas,

analyzed: pauṇḍrakaḥ vāsudeva iti sau lokeṣu viśrutaḥ
translated: He who is known in the worlds as Vasudeva of Pundra,

original: caturyuḥ sa mahārāja bhoja indrasakho balī
analyzed: caturyuḥ sa mahā rāja bhojaḥ indra sakhaḥ balī
translated: O great king, he is the powerful Bhoja, Indra's friend, the conqueror of the four directions,

analyzed: vidyā balāt yaḥ vyajayat
translated: Who conquered the Pandyas, Krathakas and Kaishikas through the power of his knowledge,

analyzed: bhrātā yasya āhṛtiḥ śūraḥ jāmadagnya samaḥ yudhi
translated: Whose brother is the brave Ahriti, equal to Jamadagni's son in battle,

original: sa bhakto māgadhaṃ rājā bhīṣmakaḥ paravīrahā
analyzed: sa bhaktaḥ māgadham rājā bhīṣmakaḥ para vīra hā
translated: That king of Magadha, Bhishmaka, the slayer of enemy heroes,

original: priyāṇy ācarataḥ prahvān sadā saṃbandhinaḥ sataḥ
analyzed: priyāṇi ācarataḥ prahvān sadā saṃbandhinaḥ sataḥ
translated: Who always acts affectionately towards his humble relatives,

original: bhajato na bhajaty asmān apriyeṣu vyavasthitaḥ
analyzed: bhajataḥ na bhajati asmān apriyeṣu vyavasthitaḥ
translated: He does not favor us who favor him, but remains hostile to those he dislikes.

original: na kulaṃ na balaṃ rājann abhijānaṃs tathātmanaḥ
analyzed: na kulam na balam rājan abhijānan tathā ātmanaḥ
translated: Not recognizing his own family and strength, O king,

analyzed: paśyamānaḥ yaśaḥ dīptam jarāsaṃdham upāśritaḥ
translated: and seeing the blazing fame of Jarasandha, he has resorted to him.

analyzed: udīcya bhojāḥ ca tathā kulāni aṣṭādaśa abhibho
translated: The eighteen tribes of the Udicyas and Bhojas,

analyzed: jarāsaṃdha bhayāt eva pratīcīm diśam āśritāḥ
translated: out of fear of Jarasandha, have taken refuge in the western direction.

analyzed: śūrasenāḥ bhadrakārāḥ bodhāḥ śālvāḥ paṭaccarāḥ
translated: The Surasenas, Bhadrakaras, Bodhas, Shalvas, Patacchas,

original: sustharāś ca sukuṭṭāś ca kuṇindāḥ kuntibhiḥ saha
analyzed: sustharāḥ ca sukuṭṭāḥ ca kuṇindāḥ kuntibhiḥ saha
translated: Susthuras, Sukuttas, Kunindas with the Kuntis,

analyzed: śālveyānām ca rājānaḥ sodarya anucaraiḥ saha
translated: the Shalveyas, and the kings of the Sodaryas with their followers,

original: dakṣiṇā ye ca pāñcālāḥ pūrvāḥ kuntiṣu kośalāḥ
analyzed: dakṣiṇāḥ ye ca pāñcālāḥ pūrvāḥ kuntiṣu kośalāḥ
translated: the Panchalas of the south, the eastern Kuntis and Koshalas,

analyzed: tathā uttarām diśam ca api parityajya bhaya arditāḥ
translated: and out of fear, abandoning the northern direction,

original: matsyāḥ saṃnyastapādāś ca dakṣiṇāṃ diśam āśritāḥ
analyzed: matsyāḥ saṃnyasta pādāḥ ca dakṣiṇām diśam āśritāḥ
translated: the Matsyas, Sannyastapadas, and others have taken refuge in the southern direction.

analyzed: tathā eva sarva pāñcālāḥ jarāsaṃdha bhaya arditāḥ
translated: In the same way, all the Panchalas, afflicted by fear of Jarasandha,

analyzed: sva rāṣṭram saṃparityajya vidrutāḥ sarvatodiśam
translated: have abandoned their own country and fled in all directions.

original: agrato hy asya pāñcālās tatrānīke mahātmanaḥ
analyzed: agratas hi asya pāñcālāḥ tatra anīke mahātmanaḥ
translated: The Panchalas are in front of his army, in the vanguard of that great-souled one,

analyzed: a nirgate sāra bale māgadhebhyaḥ girivrajāt
translated: before the main force of Magadha has come out from Girivraja.

original: kasya cit tv atha kālasya kaṃso nirmathya bāndhavān
analyzed: kasya cit tu atha kālasya kaṃsaḥ nirmathya bāndhavān
translated: After some time, Kamsa, having destroyed his relatives,

analyzed: bārhadratha sute devyau upāgacchat vṛthāmatiḥ
translated: the foolish-minded one approached the two daughters of the wife of Bārhadratha, the goddesses.

original: astiḥ prāptiś ca nāmnā te sahadevānuje 'bale
analyzed: astiḥ prāptiḥ ca nāmnā te sahadeva anuje bale
translated: Those two powerless ones, named Asti and Prāpti, were the younger sisters of Sahadeva.

original: balena tena sa jñātīn abhibhūya vṛthāmatiḥ
analyzed: balena tena sa jñātīn abhibhūya vṛthāmatiḥ
translated: With that strength, the foolish-minded one, having overpowered his relatives,

analyzed: śraiṣṭhyam prāptaḥ sa tasya āsīt atīva apanayaḥ mahān
translated: attained supremacy, which was a great humiliation for him.

analyzed: bhoja rājanya vṛddhaiḥ tu pīḍyamānaiḥ durātmanā
translated: But the elders of the Bhoja royal lineage, oppressed by the evil-minded one,

analyzed: jñāti trāṇam abhīpsadbhiḥ asmad saṃbhāvanā kṛtā
translated: desiring the protection of their relatives, made an alliance with us.

analyzed: dattvā akrūrāya sutanum tām āhuka sutām tadā
translated: Having given that beautiful daughter of Āhuka to Akrūra,

analyzed: saṃkarṣaṇa dvitīyena jñāti kāryam mayā kṛtam
translated: the task of the relatives was done by me, with Saṅkarṣaṇa as my second.

original: hatau kaṃsasunāmānau mayā rāmeṇa cāpy uta
analyzed: hatau kaṃsa sunāmānau mayā rāmeṇa ca api uta
translated: Kamsa and Sunāman were killed by me and Rāma.

analyzed: hatvā kaṃsam tathā eva ājau jarāsaṃdhasya bibhyatā
translated: Having killed Kamsa in battle, fearing Jarāsandha,

analyzed: mayā rāmeṇa ca anyatra jñātayaḥ paripālitāḥ
translated: the relatives were protected by me and Rāma elsewhere.

analyzed: bhaye tu samupakrānte jarāsaṃdhe samudyate
translated: But when the danger arose, with Jarāsandha ready to attack,

analyzed: mantraḥ yam mantritaḥ rājan kulaiḥ aṣṭādaśa avaraiḥ
translated: this counsel was given, O king, by the eighteen clans and others:

analyzed: an āramantaḥ nighnantaḥ mahā astraiḥ śata ghātibhiḥ
translated: Without resting, killing with great weapons that strike a hundred times,

original: na hanyāma vayaṃ tasya tribhir varṣaśatair balam
analyzed: na hanyāma vayam tasya tribhiḥ varṣa śataiḥ balam
translated: We could not have defeated him in three hundred years.

original: tasya hy amarasaṃkāśau balena balināṃ varau
analyzed: tasya hi amara saṃkāśau balena balinām varau
translated: He had two foremost of warriors, resembling the immortals,

analyzed: nāmabhyām haṃsa ḍibhakau iti āstām yodha sattamau
translated: called Hamsa and Dibhaka, who were the foremost of the strong.

original: tāv ubhau sahitau vīrau jarāsaṃdhaś ca vīryavān
analyzed: tau ubhau sahitau vīrau jarāsaṃdhaḥ ca vīryavān
translated: Those two heroes and the powerful Jarasandha,

original: trayas trayāṇāṃ lokānāṃ paryāptā iti me matiḥ
analyzed: trayaḥ trayāṇām lokānām paryāptāḥ iti me matiḥ
translated: these three, I think, would have been sufficient for the three worlds.

original: na hi kevalam asmākaṃ yāvanto 'nye ca pārthivāḥ
analyzed: na hi kevalam asmākam yāvantaḥ nye ca pārthivāḥ
translated: Not only we, but all the other kings,

original: tathaiva teṣām āsīc ca buddhir buddhimatāṃ vara
analyzed: tathā eva teṣām āsīt ca buddhiḥ buddhimatām vara
translated: had the same idea, O best of the wise.

analyzed: aṣṭādaśa mayā tasya saṃgrāmāḥ roma harṣaṇaḥ
translated: Eighteen times I have given him battle, making the hair stand on end,

original: dattā na ca hato rājañ jarāsaṃdho mahābalaḥ
analyzed: dattāḥ na ca hataḥ rājam jarāsaṃdhaḥ mahā balaḥ
translated: but, O king, the greatly powerful Jarasandha was not slain.

original: atha haṃsa iti khyātaḥ kaś cid āsīn mahān nṛpaḥ
analyzed: atha haṃsaḥ iti khyātaḥ kaḥ cit āsīt mahān nṛpaḥ
translated: Then there was a great king known as Hamsa.

analyzed: sa ca anyaiḥ sahitaḥ rājan saṃgrāme ṣṭādaśa avaraiḥ
translated: He, along with others, O king, in eighteen battles,

original: hato haṃsa iti proktam atha kenāpi bhārata
analyzed: hataḥ haṃsaḥ iti proktam atha kena api bhārata
translated: was slain. This is what was said by someone, O Bharata.

original: tac chrutvā ḍibhako rājan yamunāmbhasy amajjata
analyzed: tat śrutvā ḍibhakaḥ rājan yamunā ambhasi amajjata
translated: Hearing this, Dibhaka, O king, drowned himself in the waters of the Yamuna,

original: vinā haṃsena loke 'smin nāhaṃ jīvitum utsahe
analyzed: vinā haṃsena loke smin na aham jīvitum utsahe
translated: saying, Without Hamsa, I am not able to live in this world.

original: ity etāṃ matim āsthāya ḍibhako nidhanaṃ gataḥ
analyzed: iti etām matim āsthāya ḍibhakaḥ nidhanam gataḥ
translated: Having formed this resolution, Dibhaka met his death.

original: tathā tu ḍibhakaṃ śrutvā haṃsaḥ parapuraṃjayaḥ
analyzed: tathā tu ḍibhakam śrutvā haṃsaḥ para puraṃjayaḥ
translated: Hearing of the death of Dibhaka, the swan, the conqueror of enemy cities,

analyzed: prapede yamunām eva saḥ u pi tasyām nyamajjata  tau sa rājā jarāsaṃdhaḥ śrutvā apsu nidhanam gatau
translated: went to the Yamuna river and he too drowned in it.🔽Hearing that they had both met their death in the water,

analyzed: sva puram śūrasenānām prayayau bharata ṛṣabha
translated: king Jarasandha, O best of the Bharata race, went to his own city of Surasenas.

original: tato vayam amitraghna tasmin pratigate nṛpe
analyzed: tatas vayam amitra ghna tasmin pratigate nṛpe
translated: O slayer of foes, when that king had left,

analyzed: punar ānanditāḥ sarve mathurāyām vasāmahe  yadā tu abhyetya pitaram sā vai rājīva locanā
translated: we all became happy again and continued to live in Mathura.🔽When that lotus-eyed daughter of Kamsa's wife,

original: kaṃsabhāryā jarāsaṃdhaṃ duhitā māgadhaṃ nṛpam🔽codayaty eva rājendra pativyasanaduḥkhitā
analyzed: kaṃsa bhāryā jarāsaṃdham duhitā māgadham nṛpam  codayati eva rāja indra pati vyasana duḥkhitā
translated: approached her father, the king of Magadha, Jarasandha,🔽and repeatedly urged him, O lord of kings, afflicted with the grief of her husband's calamity,

original: patighnaṃ me jahīty evaṃ punaḥ punar ariṃdama
analyzed: pati ghnam me jahi iti evam punar punar ariṃdama
translated: saying, Kill my husband's slayer, O chastiser of foes,

original: tato vayaṃ mahārāja taṃ mantraṃ pūrvamantritam
analyzed: tatas vayam mahā rāja tam mantram pūrva mantritam
translated: then, O great king, remembering that former counsel,

analyzed: saṃsmarantaḥ vimanasaḥ vyapayātāḥ narādhipa
translated: we left in dejection, O lord of men.

original: pṛthaktvena drutā rājan saṃkṣipya mahatīṃ śriyam
analyzed: pṛthaktvena drutāḥ rājan saṃkṣipya mahatīm śriyam
translated: Scattering our great wealth, we fled separately, O king,

analyzed: prapatāmaḥ bhayāt tasya sa dhana jñāti bāndhavāḥ
translated: out of fear for him, with our wealth, kinsmen and relatives.

original: iti saṃcintya sarve sma pratīcīṃ diśam āśritāḥ
analyzed: iti saṃcintya sarve sma pratīcīm diśam āśritāḥ
translated: Thinking thus, we all took refuge in the western direction.

analyzed: kuśasthalīm purīm ramyām raivatena upaśobhitām
translated: The beautiful city of Kushasthali, adorned by Raivata,

original: punar niveśanaṃ tasyāṃ kṛtavanto vayaṃ nṛpa
analyzed: punar niveśanam tasyām kṛtavantaḥ vayam nṛpa
translated: O king, we have again made our residence there.

analyzed: tathā eva durga saṃskāram devaiḥ api durāsadam
translated: And we have fortified it in such a way that it is difficult for even the gods to conquer.

original: striyo 'pi yasyāṃ yudhyeyuḥ kiṃ punar vṛṣṇipuṃgavāḥ
analyzed: striyaḥ pi yasyām yudhyeyuḥ kim punar vṛṣṇi puṃgavāḥ
translated: Even women can fight in it, what to speak of the bulls among the Vrishnis.

analyzed: tasyām vayam amitra ghna nivasāmaḥ kutobhayāḥ
translated: O slayer of enemies, we live there without any fear.

original: ālokya girimukhyaṃ taṃ mādhavītīrtham eva ca
analyzed: ālokya giri mukhyam tam mādhavī tīrtham eva ca
translated: Having seen that chief of mountains and the Madhavi tirtha,

analyzed: mādhavāḥ kuru śārdūla parām mudam avāpnuvan
translated: the Madhavas, O tiger among the Kurus, attained supreme joy.

analyzed: evam vayam jarāsaṃdhāt āditas kṛta kilbiṣāḥ
translated: Thus, from the very beginning, we have incurred the enmity of Jarasandha,

analyzed: sāmarthyavantaḥ saṃbandhāt bhavantam samupāśritāḥ
translated: and being powerful, we have sought refuge in you.

analyzed: tri yojana āyatam sadma tri skandham yojanāt adhi  yojana ante śata dvāram vikrama krama toraṇam
translated: The palace is three yojanas long, three yojanas wide,🔽and at the end of each yojana, there are a hundred gates with arches of heroism.

analyzed: aṣṭādaśa avaraiḥ naddham kṣatriyaiḥ yuddha durmadaiḥ
translated: It is surrounded by eighteen thousand Kshatriyas, invincible in battle.

original: aṣṭādaśa sahasrāṇi vrātānāṃ santi naḥ kule
analyzed: aṣṭādaśa sahasrāṇi vrātānām santi naḥ kule
translated: In our family, there are eighteen thousand clans.

analyzed: āhukasya śatam putrāḥ ekaikaḥ tri śata avaraḥ
translated: Ahuk's sons are a hundred, each with three hundred followers.

analyzed: cārudeṣṇaḥ saha bhrātrā sātyakiḥ
translated: Charudeshna with his brother, Chakradeva, and Satyaki,

original: ahaṃ ca rauhiṇeyaś ca sāmbaḥ śaurisamo yudhi
analyzed: aham ca rauhiṇeyaḥ ca sāmbaḥ śauri samaḥ yudhi
translated: I, Rohini's son, Samba, equal to Shouri in battle,

original: evam ete rathāḥ sapta rājann anyān nibodha me
analyzed: evam ete rathāḥ sapta rājan anyān nibodha me
translated: Thus these seven chariots, O king, know others from me.

analyzed: kṛtavarmā anādhṛṣṭiḥ samīkaḥ samitiṃjayaḥ
translated: Kritavarma, Anadhrishti, Sameeka, Samitiinjaya,

original: kahvaḥ śaṅkur nidāntaś ca saptaivaite mahārathāḥ
analyzed: kahvaḥ śaṅkuḥ nidāntaḥ ca sapta eva ete mahā rathāḥ
translated: Kaha, Shankhu, Nidanta, these seven are great charioteers.

analyzed: pradyumnaḥ ca aniruddhaḥ ca bhānuḥ akrūra sāraṇau
translated: Pradyumna, Aniruddha, Bhanu, Akrura, Sarana,

original: niśaṭhaś ca gadaś caiva sapta caite mahārathāḥ
analyzed: niśaṭhaḥ ca gadaḥ ca eva sapta ca ete mahā rathāḥ
translated: Nishtha and Gada, these seven are great charioteers.

analyzed: vitadruḥ jhalli babhrū ca uddhavaḥ vidūrathaḥ
translated: Vitadru, Jhalli, Babhru, Uddhava, Viduratha,

analyzed: vasudeva ugrasenau ca saptā ete mantri puṃgavāḥ
translated: Vasudeva, Ugrasena, these seven are the best ministers.

analyzed: prasenajit ca yamalaḥ rāja rāja guṇa anvitaḥ
translated: Prasenajit, the twins, endowed with the qualities of the king of kings,

original: syamantako maṇir yasya rukmaṃ nisravate bahu
analyzed: syamantakaḥ maṇiḥ yasya rukmam nisravate bahu
translated: Whose Syamantaka jewel drips much gold,

original: putrau cāndhakabhojasya vṛddho rājā ca te daśa
analyzed: putrau ca andhaka bhojasya vṛddhaḥ rājā ca te daśa
translated: And the two sons of Andhaka and Bhoja, the old king, they are ten.

analyzed: loka saṃhananāḥ vīrāḥ vīryavantaḥ mahā balāḥ
translated: The heroes who are capable of destroying the world, powerful, greatly strong,

analyzed: smarantaḥ madhyamam deśam vṛṣṇi madhye gata vyathāḥ
translated: Remembering the central country, their pain gone in the midst of the Vrishnis,

original: śrībhagavān🔽pāṇḍavaiś cāpi satataṃ nāthavanto vayaṃ nṛpa
analyzed: pāṇḍavaiḥ ca api satatam nāthavantaḥ vayam nṛpa
translated: The Blessed Lord🔽And we are always protected by the Pandavas, O king.

original: sa tvaṃ samrāḍguṇair yuktaḥ sadā bharatasattama
analyzed: sa tvam samrāj guṇaiḥ yuktaḥ sadā bharata sattama
translated: You, O best of the Bharata race, endowed with the qualities of an emperor,

original: kṣatre samrājam ātmānaṃ kartum arhasi bhārata
analyzed: kṣatre samrājam ātmānam kartum arhasi bhārata
translated: You should make yourself the emperor among the Kshatriyas, O Bharata.

analyzed: duryodhanam śāṃtanavam droṇam droṇāyanim kṛpam
translated: Duryodhana, Shantanu's son, Drona, Drona's son, Kripa,

original: karṇaṃ ca śiśupālaṃ ca rukmiṇaṃ ca dhanurdharam
analyzed: karṇam ca śiśupālam ca rukmiṇam ca dhanurdharam
translated: Karna, Shishupala, Rukmini's bowman son,

original: ekalavyaṃ drumaṃ śvetaṃ śalyaṃ śakunim eva ca
analyzed: ekalavyam drumam śvetam śalyam śakunim eva ca
translated: Ekalavya, Druma, Shveta, Shalya, Shakuni,

original: etān ajitvā saṃgrāme kathaṃ śaknoṣi taṃ kratum
analyzed: etān a jitvā saṃgrāme katham śaknoṣi tam kratum
translated: Without defeating them in battle, how can you perform that sacrifice?

analyzed: athā ete gauraveṇa eva na yotsyanti narādhipāḥ
translated: If these kings do not fight out of respect,

original: ekas tatra balonmattaḥ karṇo vaikartano vṛṣā
analyzed: ekaḥ tatra bala unmattaḥ karṇaḥ vaikartanaḥ vṛṣā
translated: Then there is only one, intoxicated with strength, Karna Vaikartana Vrisha,

analyzed: yotsyate sa bala amarṣī divya astra bala garvitaḥ
translated: Who will fight out of impatience and pride in his divine weapons and strength.

original: na tu śakyaṃ jarāsaṃdhe jīvamāne mahābale
analyzed: na tu śakyam jarāsaṃdhe jīvamāne mahā bale
translated: But as long as the greatly powerful Jarasandha lives,

original: rājasūyas tvayā prāptum eṣā rājan matir mama
analyzed: rājasūyaḥ tvayā prāptum eṣā rājan matiḥ mama
translated: It is not possible for you to obtain the Rajasuya sacrifice, this is my opinion, O king.

original: tena ruddhā hi rājānaḥ sarve jitvā girivraje
analyzed: tena ruddhāḥ hi rājānaḥ sarve jitvā girivraje
translated: For all the kings, having been defeated, are imprisoned in Girivraja by him,

analyzed: kandarāyām giri indrasya siṃhena iva mahā dvipāḥ
translated: In the cave of the king of mountains, like great elephants by a lion.

analyzed: saḥ pi rājā jarāsaṃdhaḥ yiyakṣuḥ vasudhā adhipaiḥ

analyzed: abhiṣiktaiḥ ca rājanyaiḥ sahasraiḥ uta ca aṣṭabhiḥ

analyzed: ārādhya hi mahādevam nirjitāḥ tena pārthivāḥ

analyzed: nivasāma tathā adya api sa dhana jñāti bāndhavāḥ

translated: Having crossed the ocean, he is desirous of performing a great sacrifice to the Supreme God.

analyzed: jarāsaṃdha vadha upāyaḥ cintyatām bharata ṛṣabha

analyzed: iti eṣā me matiḥ rājan yathā vā manyase nagha
translated: This is my opinion, O king. Or, O sinless one, whatever you think,

translated: Yudhisthira said:

analyzed: uktam tvayā buddhimatā yat na anyaḥ vaktum arhati

analyzed: saṃśayānām hi nirmoktā tvat nā anyaḥ vidyate bhuvi

original: pareṇa samavetas tu yaḥ praśastaḥ sa pūjyate
analyzed: pareṇa samavetaḥ tu yaḥ praśastaḥ sa pūjyate

analyzed: ārambhe pārameṣṭhyam tu na prāpyam iti me matiḥ

analyzed: evam eva abhijānanti kule jātāḥ manasvinaḥ

analyzed: kaḥ cit kadā cit eteṣām bhavet śreṣṭhaḥ janārdana
translated: Sometimes, one of these may become the best, O Janardana.

analyzed: vayam ca eva mahābhāga jarāsaṃdha bhayāt tadā
translated: O greatly fortunate one, we were also afraid of Jarasandha

original: śaṅkitāḥ sma mahābhāga daurātmyāt tasya cānagha
analyzed: śaṅkitāḥ sma mahābhāga daurātmyāt tasya ca anagha
translated: and, O greatly fortunate one, we were suspicious of his wickedness, O sinless one.

original: ahaṃ hi tava durdharṣa bhujavīryāśrayaḥ prabho
analyzed: aham hi tava durdharṣa bhuja vīrya āśrayaḥ prabho
translated: O invincible one, I am the one who has taken refuge in the strength of your arms, O lord.

analyzed: na ātmānam balinam manye tvayi tasmāt viśaṅkite
translated: I do not consider myself strong, therefore I am suspicious of you.🔽O Madhava, I have been thinking again and again

original: tvatsakāśāc ca rāmāc ca bhīmasenāc ca mādhava
analyzed: tvad sakāśāt ca rāmāt ca bhīmasenāt ca mādhava
translated: whether I can be killed by you, Rama, Bhimasena,

analyzed: arjunāt vā mahā bāho hantum śakyaḥ na vā iti vai

analyzed: evam jānan hi vārṣṇeya vimṛśāmi punar punar
translated: Knowing this, O Varshneya, I am repeatedly reflecting

analyzed: tvam me sarva kāryeṣu keśava
translated: You are my authority in all matters, O Keshava.

original: tac chrutvā cābravīd bhīmo vākyaṃ vākyaviśāradaḥ
analyzed: tat śrutvā ca abravīt bhīmaḥ vākyam vākya viśāradaḥ
translated: Hearing this, Bhima, skilled in speech, said these words:

analyzed: bhīmaḥ uvāca
translated: Bhima said:

analyzed: anārambha paraḥ rājā valmīkaḥ iva sīdati  durbalaḥ ca anupāyena balinam yaḥ dhitiṣṭhati
translated: A king who is averse to action sinks like an ant-hill.🔽And one who, being weak, relies on a strong one without proper means,

original: atandritas tu prāyeṇa durbalo balinaṃ ripum
analyzed: atandritaḥ tu prāyeṇa durbalaḥ balinam ripum
translated: But one who is diligent can usually defeat a strong enemy,

analyzed: jayet samyak nayaḥ rājan nītyā arthān ātmanaḥ hitān

analyzed: kṛṣṇe nayaḥ mayi balam jayaḥ pārthe dhanaṃjaye

analyzed: māgadham sādhayiṣyāmaḥ vayam trayaḥ iva agnayaḥ

analyzed: tvad buddhi balam āśritya sarvam prāpsyati dharmarāj

analyzed: smākam hi govinda yeṣām nāthaḥ bhavān sadā

analyzed: kṛṣṇaḥ uvāca
translated: Krishna said:

analyzed: sarvān vaṃśyān anumṛśan ekam eva satām yuge  hitvā karān yauvanāśvaḥ pālanāt ca bhagīrathaḥ

analyzed: kārtavīryaḥ tapaḥ yogāt balāt tu bharataḥ vibhuḥ

analyzed: katham jitvā punar yūyam asmān saṃpratiyāsyatha

analyzed: nanu sma māgadham sarve pratibādhema yat vayam

analyzed: jarāsaṃdhena rājānaḥ tatas krūram prapatsyate

analyzed: jayet yaḥ ca jarāsaṃdham sa samrāj niyatam bhavet

translated: Yudhishthira said:

analyzed: samrāj guṇam abhīpsan vai yuṣmān sva artha parāyaṇaḥ
translated: Desiring the qualities of an emperor, I, devoted to my own interests,

analyzed: katham prahiṇuyām bhīmam balāt kevala sāhasāt

original: bhīmārjunāv ubhau netre mano manye janārdanam
analyzed: bhīma arjunau ubhau netre manaḥ manye janārdanam
translated: Bhima and Arjuna are my two eyes, and I consider Janardana to be my mind.

analyzed: manaḥ cakṣuḥ vihīnasya kīdṛśam jīvitam bhavet
translated: What kind of life would I have if I were deprived of mind and eyes?

analyzed: jarāsaṃdha balam prāpya duṣpāram bhīma vikramam
translated: Having reached the army of Jarasandha, difficult to cross and of terrible prowess,

original: śramo hi vaḥ parājayyāt kim u tatra viceṣṭitam
analyzed: śramaḥ hi vaḥ parājayyāt kim u tatra viceṣṭitam
translated: Exertion would lead to your defeat - what kind of action would there be there?

analyzed: asmin artha antare yuktam anarthaḥ pratipadyate
translated: In this matter, what is proper leads to what is improper.

analyzed: yathā aham vimṛśāmi ekaḥ tat tāvat śrūyatām mama
translated: As I consider it alone, let that be heard from me first.

analyzed: tasmāt na pratipattiḥ tu kāryā yuktā matā mama

analyzed: saṃnyāsam rocaye sādhu kāryasya asya janārdana
translated: I consider renunciation to be good in this matter, O Janardana.

analyzed: pratihanti manaḥ me dya rājasūyaḥ durāsadaḥ
translated: Today the Rajasuya sacrifice, which is difficult to perform, obstructs my mind.

analyzed: vaiśaṃpāyanaḥ uvāca
translated: Vaishampayana said:

original: pārthaḥ prāpya dhanuḥśreṣṭham akṣayyau ca maheṣudhī
analyzed: pārthaḥ prāpya dhanuḥ śreṣṭham akṣayyau ca mahā iṣudhī
translated: Having obtained the best of bows and the two great inexhaustible quivers,

original: rathaṃ dhvajaṃ sabhāṃ caiva yudhiṣṭhiram abhāṣata
analyzed: ratham dhvajam sabhām ca eva yudhiṣṭhiram abhāṣata
translated: The chariot, the flag and the assembly hall, Partha spoke to Yudhishthira:

original: dhanur astraṃ śarā vīryaṃ pakṣo bhūmir yaśo balam
analyzed: dhanuḥ astram śarāḥ vīryam pakṣaḥ bhūmiḥ yaśaḥ balam

original: prāptam etan mayā rājan duṣprāpaṃ yad abhīpsitam
analyzed: prāptam etat mayā rājan duṣprāpam yat abhīpsitam
translated: I have obtained this, O king, which is difficult to obtain and desired.

original: kule janma praśaṃsanti vaidyāḥ sādhu suniṣṭhitāḥ
analyzed: kule janma praśaṃsanti vaidyāḥ sādhu su niṣṭhitāḥ
translated: The learned ones who are well-established praise birth in a noble family.

original: balena sadṛśaṃ nāsti vīryaṃ tu mama rocate🔽kṛtavīryakule jāto nirvīryaḥ kiṃ kariṣyati
analyzed: balena sadṛśam nā asti vīryam tu mama rocate  kṛtavīrya kule jātaḥ nirvīryaḥ kim kariṣyati
translated: There is nothing equal to strength, but I like prowess.🔽What can a person born in a family of accomplished heroes do if he is devoid of heroism?

original: nirvīrye tu kule jāto vīryavāṃs tu viśiṣyate
analyzed: nirvīrye tu kule jātaḥ vīryavān tu viśiṣyate
translated: But one born in a family devoid of heroism, if he is heroic, excels.

original: kṣatriyaḥ sarvaśo rājan yasya vṛttiḥ parājaye
analyzed: kṣatriyaḥ sarvaśas rājan yasya vṛttiḥ parājaye

analyzed: sarvaiḥ api guṇaiḥ hīnaḥ vīryavān hi taret ripūn
translated: Even if he is devoid of all qualities, a heroic person can overcome his enemies.

original: sarvair api guṇair yukto nirvīryaḥ kiṃ kariṣyati
analyzed: sarvaiḥ api guṇaiḥ yuktaḥ nirvīryaḥ kim kariṣyati
translated: What can a person devoid of heroism do, even if he is endowed with all qualities?

original: dravyabhūtā guṇāḥ sarve tiṣṭhanti hi parākrame
analyzed: dravya bhūtāḥ guṇāḥ sarve tiṣṭhanti hi parākrame
translated: All the qualities exist in heroism, as if they were material.

original: jayasya hetuḥ siddhir hi karma daivaṃ ca saṃśritam
analyzed: jayasya hetuḥ siddhiḥ hi karma daivam ca saṃśritam
translated: Success depends on action and destiny for victory.

original: saṃyukto hi balaiḥ kaś cit pramādān nopayujyate
analyzed: saṃyuktaḥ hi balaiḥ kaḥ cit pramādāt na upayujyate
translated: Even if one is endowed with strength, he may not be employed due to negligence.

original: tena dvāreṇa śatrubhyaḥ kṣīyate sabalo ripuḥ
analyzed: tena dvāreṇa śatrubhyaḥ kṣīyate sa balaḥ ripuḥ
translated: Through that door, the enemy along with his army is destroyed by the enemies.

analyzed: dainyam yathā abalavati tathā mohaḥ bala anvite
translated: As weakness is in the strong, so delusion is in the powerful.

original: tāv ubhau nāśakau hetū rājñā tyājyau jayārthinā🔽jarāsaṃdhavināśaṃ ca rājñāṃ ca parimokṣaṇam
analyzed: tau ubhau na aśakau hetū rājñā tyājyau jaya arthinā  jarāsaṃdha vināśam ca rājñām ca parimokṣaṇam
translated: These two causes of destruction should be abandoned by a king who desires victory.🔽If we were to perform a sacrifice for the destruction of Jarasandha and the liberation of the kings,

original: yadi kuryāma yajñārthaṃ kiṃ tataḥ paramaṃ bhavet
analyzed: yadi kuryāma yajña artham kim tatas paramam bhavet
translated: what could be greater than that?

analyzed: anārambhe tu niyataḥ bhavet aguṇa niścayaḥ
translated: But if one does not undertake [action], one is certainly bound to be devoid of qualities.

original: guṇān niḥsaṃśayād rājan nairguṇyaṃ manyase katham
analyzed: guṇān niḥsaṃśayāt rājan nairguṇyam manyase katham
translated: O king, how can you consider non-attachment to be superior to qualities, which are free from doubt?

original: kāṣāyaṃ sulabhaṃ paścān munīnāṃ śamam icchatām
analyzed: kāṣāyam sulabham paścāt munīnām śamam icchatām
translated: The ochre robes are easily obtained later by the sages who desire peace.

original: sāmrājyaṃ tu tavecchanto vayaṃ yotsyāmahe paraiḥ

analyzed: vaiśyāt balāt gṛhītvā te vihṛtya ca mahā rathāḥ
translated: and having played, those mighty warriors forcibly took from a vaishya

analyzed: niveśanam atha ājagmuḥ jarāsaṃdhasya dhīmataḥ
translated: They then went to the abode of the wise Jarasandha,

translated: shone forth, O great king, of those mighty men.

analyzed: tān dṛṣṭvā dvirada prakhyām śāla skandhān iva udgatān  vyūḍha uraskān māgadhānām vismayaḥ samajāyata

analyzed: advāreṇa abhyavaskandya viviśuḥ māgadha ālayam
translated: Leaping over the wall, they entered the abode of the Magadhas.

original: arvāṅ niśīthāt paratas tvayā sārdhaṃ vadiṣyataḥ
analyzed: arvāk niśīthāt paratas tvayā sārdham vadiṣyataḥ

analyzed: yajñāgāre sthāpayitvā rājā rājagṛham gataḥ
translated: The king, having placed them in the sacrificial house, went to the royal palace.

original: tato 'rdharātre saṃprāpte yāto yatra sthitā dvijāḥ
analyzed: tatas ṛdharātre saṃprāpte yātaḥ yatra sthitāḥ dvijāḥ

translated: Having heard that the assembled Brahmins

translated: Had seen them in an unprecedented attire, the best of kings,

analyzed: upatasthe jarāsaṃdhaḥ vismitaḥ ca abhavat tadā

original: te tu dṛṣṭvaiva rājānaṃ jarāsaṃdhaṃ nararṣabhāḥ
analyzed: te tu dṛṣṭvā eva rājānam jarāsaṃdham nara ṛṣabhāḥ
translated: Those bulls among men, having seen King Jarasandha,

analyzed: satvam tejaḥ balam dhairyam gāmbhīryam iva mūrtimān
translated: Who embodied goodness, splendor, strength, courage and gravity,

translated: Spoke these words, O best of the Bharata lineage,

analyzed: rājan viddhi atithīn asmān arthinaḥ dūram āgatān
translated: O king, know us to be guests, seekers, come from afar.

original: tan naḥ prayaccha bhadraṃ te yad vayaṃ kāmayāmahe🔽kiṃ durmarṣaṃ titikṣūṇāṃ kim akāryam asādhubhiḥ

analyzed: kim adeyam vadānyānām kaḥ paraḥ sama darśinām  yaḥ nityena śarīreṇa satām geyam yaśaḥ dhruvam

analyzed: na ācinoti svayam kalpaḥ sa vācyaḥ śocyaḥ eva saḥ

Harishchandra, Rantideva, Ucchavari, Shibi, Bali,

analyzed: vyādhaḥ kapotaḥ bahavaḥ hi adhruveṇa dhruvam gatāḥ

analyzed: svasti astu kuśalam rājan iti sarve vyavasthitāḥ

analyzed: tam nṛpam nṛpa śārdūla vipraikṣanta parasparam

translated: O lord of kings, asking them to sit, who were disguised as Brahmins.

analyzed: atha upaviviśuḥ sarve trayaḥ te puruṣa ṛṣabhāḥ
translated: Then all those three best of men sat down,

analyzed: saṃpradīptāḥ trayaḥ lakṣmyā mahā adhvare iva agnayaḥ  svaraiḥ ākṛtibhiḥ tān tu prakoṣṭhaiḥ jyā hataiḥ api
translated: like three blazing fires at a great sacrifice.🔽By their voices, their forms, their forearms marked by the bowstring,

analyzed: rājanya bandhūn vijñāya dṛṣṭa pūrvān acintayat
translated: and by their gait, he recognized them as Kshatriyas, and remembered their former enmity.

analyzed: rājanyabandhavaḥ hi ete brahma liṅgāni bibhrati
translated: For these are Kshatriyas, bearing the marks of Brahmins.

original: dadāmi bhikṣitaṃ tebhya ātmānam api dustyajam
analyzed: dadāmi bhikṣitam tebhyaḥ ātmānam api dustyajam
translated: I will give them what they beg, even myself, so difficult to abandon.

analyzed: baleḥ na śrūyate kīrtiḥ vitatā dikṣu sarvatas  aiśvaryāt bhraṃśitaḥ ca api vipra vyājena viṣṇunā
translated: The fame of Bali is not heard spreading everywhere in all directions,🔽and he has been deposed from his sovereignty by Vishnu under the pretext of a Brahmin.

analyzed: śriyam jihīrṣatā indrasya viṣṇave dvija rūpiṇe
translated: Desiring Indra's prosperity, he gave it to Vishnu in the form of a Brahmin.

original: jānann api mahīṃ prādād vāryamāṇo 'pi daityarāṭ
analyzed: jānan api mahīm prādāt vāryamāṇaḥ pi daitya rāj
translated: Even knowing this, the king of the demons gave away the earth, though forbidden.

original: vijitā brāhmaṇārthāya ko nv arthaḥ kṣatrabandhunā
analyzed: vijitāḥ brāhmaṇa arthāya kaḥ nu arthaḥ kṣatrabandhunā

analyzed: dehena tapamānena na īheta vipulam yaśaḥ

analyzed: iti udāra matiḥ prāha kṛṣṇa arjuna vṛkodarān
translated: Thus, the one of noble mind spoke to Krishna, Arjuna and Vrikodara:

analyzed: he viprāḥ kāmaḥ dadāmi ātmā śiraḥ ca

analyzed: tān uvāca jarāsaṃdhaḥ satya saṃdhaḥ narādhipaḥ
translated: To them, the truthful king Jarasandha said:

analyzed: harim indram samīram ca līlā mānuṣa vigrahān
translated: Hari, Indra and Vayu, who have assumed human forms as a pastime,

original: vigarhamāṇaḥ kauravya veṣagrahaṇakāraṇāt🔽na snātakavratā viprā bahirmālyānulepanāḥ
analyzed: vigarhamāṇaḥ kauravya veṣa grahaṇa kāraṇāt  na snātaka vratāḥ viprāḥ bahis mālya anulepanāḥ
translated: are being censured, O descendant of Kuru, for taking on these disguises.

analyzed: bhavanti iti nṛ loke smin viditam mama sarvaśas
translated: I know for certain that in this world of men, Brahmanas who have taken the Snataka vows do not wear garlands and anointments.

original: te yūyaṃ puṣpavantaś ca bhujair jyāghātalakṣaṇaiḥ🔽kṛtaśmaśrumukhā raktā raktatīkṣṇanakhāṅkurāḥ
analyzed: te yūyam puṣpavantaḥ ca bhujaiḥ jyā ghāta lakṣaṇaiḥ  kṛta śmaśru mukhāḥ raktāḥ rakta tīkṣṇa nakha aṅkurāḥ
translated: You, however, are wearing flowers, your arms bear the marks of bowstrings,🔽your beards and faces are red, your nails and sprouts are red and sharp,

analyzed: rakta uṣṇīṣa dharāḥ rakta danta paṅkti virājitāḥ
translated: you wear red turbans, and your rows of red teeth shine.

original: bibhrataḥ kṣātram ojaś ca brāhmaṇyaṃ pratijānatha
analyzed: bibhrataḥ kṣātram ojaḥ ca brāhmaṇyam pratijānatha
translated: You bear the vigor of Kshatriyas, yet claim to be Brahmanas.

analyzed: evam virāga vasanāḥ bahis mālya anulepanāḥ
translated: Thus dressed in discolored garments, wearing garlands and anointments,

original: kṣatriyā eva loke 'smin viditā mama sarvaśaḥ
analyzed: kṣatriyāḥ eva loke smin viditāḥ mama sarvaśas
translated: I know for certain that you are Kshatriyas in this world.

original: satyaṃ vadata ke yūyaṃ satyaṃ rājasu śobhate
analyzed: satyam vadata ke yūyam satyam rājasu śobhate
translated: Tell the truth, who are you? Truth shines among kings.

analyzed: iyam vasumatī satyam satya rūpāḥ mahīkṣitaḥ
translated: This earth is truth, O kings, truth is the form of the earth.

original: satye sthito vadet satyam anyathā vinaśiṣyati
analyzed: satye sthitaḥ vadet satyam anyathā vinaśiṣyati
translated: One who is established in truth should speak the truth, otherwise he will perish.

original: caityakaṃ ca gireḥ śṛṅgaṃ bhittvā kim iva sadma naḥ
analyzed: caityakam ca gireḥ śṛṅgam bhittvā kim iva sadma naḥ
translated: Having pierced the peak of Mount Chaitya, what kind of abode is this for us?

analyzed: advāreṇa praviṣṭāḥ stha nirbhayāḥ rāja kilbiṣāt
translated: You have entered without a door, fearless of the king's offense.
One should enter the house of an enemy.

original: so 'haṃ na bhavatāṃ śatrur brāhmaṇā mama devatāḥ
analyzed: saḥ ham na bhavatām śatruḥ brāhmaṇāḥ mama devatāḥ
translated: I am not your enemy, Brahmins are my deity.

analyzed: atāḍayata kim bherīḥ yuddha saṃnāha lakṣaṇāḥ
translated: Why did you beat the drums, which are a sign of preparation for battle?

analyzed: yūyam mayā na yoddhavyā
translated: You should not fight with me.

original: karma caitad viliṅgasya kiṃ vādya prasamīkṣitam
analyzed: karma ca etat viliṅgasya kim vā adya prasamīkṣitam
translated: And what is this act of a person of mixed caste being considered today?

original: vadadhvaṃ vāci vīryaṃ ca brāhmaṇasya viśeṣataḥ🔽evaṃ ca mām upasthāya kasmāc ca vidhinārhaṇām
analyzed: vadadhvam vāci vīryam ca brāhmaṇasya viśeṣataḥ  evam ca mām upasthāya kasmāt ca vidhinā arhaṇām
translated: Speak, and let the strength of speech, especially of a Brahmin, be seen.

original: praṇītāṃ no na gṛhṇīta kāryaṃ kiṃ cāsmadāgame🔽evam uktas tataḥ kṛṣṇaḥ pratyuvāca mahāmanāḥ
analyzed: praṇītām naḥ na gṛhṇīta kāryam kim ca asmad āgame  evam uktaḥ tatas kṛṣṇaḥ pratyuvāca mahā manāḥ
translated: Having thus approached me, why do you not accept the worship offered according to the prescribed rules? What is the purpose of our coming here?

analyzed: snigdha gambhīrayā vācā vākyam vākya viśāradaḥ
translated: Thus addressed, Krishna, the great-minded one, skilled in speech, replied with affectionate and deep words:

analyzed: snātaka vratinaḥ rājan brāhmaṇāḥ kṣatriyāḥ viśaḥ
translated: Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and Vaishyas who observe the vows of a Snataka, O king,

original: viśeṣaniyamāś caiṣām aviśeṣāś ca santy uta
analyzed: viśeṣa niyamāḥ ca eṣām aviśeṣāḥ ca santi uta
translated: They have specific and general rules.

original: snātakān brāhmaṇān rājan viddhy asmāṃs tvaṃ narādhipa
analyzed: snātakān brāhmaṇān rājan viddhi asmān tvam narādhipa
translated: O king, know us to be Brahmins who have completed their studies, O lord of men.

original: viśeṣavāṃś ca satataṃ kṣatriyaḥ śriyam archati
analyzed: viśeṣavān ca satatam kṣatriyaḥ śriyam archati
translated: A Kshatriya always attains prosperity through specific means.

original: puṣpavatsu dhruvā śrīś ca puṣpavantas tato vayam
analyzed: puṣpavatsu dhrīḥ śrīḥ ca puṣpavantaḥ tatas vayam
translated: Prosperity is always with those who have flowers, therefore we have flowers.

original: kṣatriyo bāhuvīryas tu na tathā vākyavīryavān
analyzed: kṣatriyaḥ bāhu vīryaḥ tu na tathā vākya vīryavān
translated: A Kshatriya has the strength of arms, not so much the strength of words.

original: apragalbhaṃ vacas tasya tasmād bārhadrathe smṛtam
analyzed: a pragalbham vacaḥ tasya tasmāt bārhadrathe smṛtam
translated: His speech is not bold, therefore it is remembered as the speech of Brihadratha.

original: svavīryaṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ ca bāhvor dhātā nyaveśayat
analyzed: sva vīryam kṣatriyāṇām ca bāhvoḥ dhātā nyaveśayat
translated: The Creator placed the strength of Kshatriyas in their arms.

original: tad didṛkṣasi ced rājan draṣṭāsy adya na saṃśayaḥ🔽advāreṇa ripor gehaṃ dvāreṇa suhṛdo gṛham
analyzed: tat didṛkṣasi ced rājan draṣṭāsi adya na saṃśayaḥ  advāreṇa ripoḥ geham dvāreṇa suhṛdaḥ gṛham
translated: If you wish to see it, O king, you will see it today, there is no doubt.

original: praviśanti sadā santo dvāraṃ no varjitaṃ tataḥ🔽kāryavanto gṛhān etya śatruto nārhaṇāṃ vayam
analyzed: praviśanti sadā santaḥ dvāram no varjitam tatas  kāryavantaḥ gṛhān etya śatrutaḥ na arhaṇām vayam
translated: The virtuous always enter the house of an enemy through the back door, and the house of a friend through the front door.🔽Therefore, the front door is avoided by them.🔽We who have come to the house for a purpose, do not accept worship from an enemy.

original: pratigṛhṇīma tad viddhi etan naḥ śāśvataṃ vratam
analyzed: pratigṛhṇīma tat viddhi etat naḥ śāśvatam vratam
translated: Know this, it is our eternal vow.

original: jarāsaṃdha uvāca🔽na smareyaṃ kadā vairaṃ kṛtaṃ yuṣmābhir ity uta
analyzed: jarāsaṃdhaḥ uvāca  na smareyam kadā vairam kṛtam yuṣmābhiḥ iti uta
translated: Jarasandha said:🔽I do not remember any enmity done by you at any time.

original: cintayaṃś ca na paśyāmi bhavatāṃ prati vaikṛtam🔽vaiśaṃpāyanaḥ
analyzed: cintayan ca na paśyāmi bhavatām prati vaikṛtam 🔽vaiśaṃpāyanaḥ
translated: Thinking about it, I do not see any offense on your part.

analyzed: evam uktaḥ bhagavatā bṛhadratha sutaḥ balī
translated: Thus addressed by the Blessed Lord, the powerful son of Brihadratha,

original: ātmany autsukam ālokya kṛṣṇam āha nṛpottamāḥ
analyzed: ātmani autsukam ālokya kṛṣṇam āha nṛpa uttamāḥ
translated: looking to his own eagerness, spoke to Krishna, O best of kings:

original: vaikṛte cāsati kathaṃ manyadhvaṃ mām anāgasam
analyzed: vaikṛte ca asati katham manyadhvam mām anāgasam
translated: When there is no fault, how do you consider me innocent?

original: ariṃ vibrūta tad viprāḥ satāṃ samaya eṣa hi
analyzed: arim vibrūta tat viprāḥ satām samayaḥ eṣa hi
translated: Tell me, O Brahmanas, this is the rule of the virtuous.

analyzed: atha dharma upaghātāt hi manaḥ samupatapyate
translated: Then, because of the injury to dharma, the mind is tormented.

analyzed: yaḥ na āgasi prasṛjati kṣatriyaḥ u pi na saṃśayaḥ
translated: Even a Kshatriya, without doubt, who inflicts it on an innocent person,

original: kṣatriyā eva loke 'smin viditaṃ mama sarvaśaḥ

analyzed: kṛtakṣaṇe ca vaidehe katham kṛṣṇaḥ tvayā arcitaḥ

translated: In this king, O king, the friend of the Parthas, the lord of the Gandharvas,

analyzed: sthite citrarathe vīre katham kṛṣṇaḥ tvayā arcitaḥ

translated: The greatly powerful Somadatta, the great chariot Somadatta,

analyzed: śakunim saubalam ca eva sindhu rājam mahā balam
translated: Śakuni, the son of Subala, and the mighty king of the Sindhus,

original: etān avamatān kṛtvā kathaṃ kṛṣṇo 'rcitas tvayā
analyzed: etān avamatān kṛtvā katham kṛṣṇaḥ rcitaḥ tvayā
